title: 113_hr3357
content: The "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" aims to assist States in enhancing the knowledge, credentials, compensation, and professional development of early childhood educators in various programs. This includes Head Start Programs, state-funded prekindergarten programs, licensed child care for prekindergarten children, and special education preschools. Grants are authorized for implementation by the Secretary of Education in collaboration with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Each State seeking a grant under the "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" must submit an application to the Secretary of Education with details of their early childhood professional development system, including collaboration with relevant stakeholders, designation of a grant program administrator, and an oversight structure. The State applying for a grant under the "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" must provide details of their professional development system, including oversight, standards, career progression, coordination with higher education bodies, articulation agreements, accessibility for working learners, and support for dual language adult learners. The State must provide support for adult learners from low-income or minority communities, use workforce data to assess needs, and ensure financing over time in their grant application for college courses. The State must use funds in accordance with the grant application for college courses. A State receiving a grant under this Act must use the funds for scholarships, support for preschool teachers, increased compensation for teachers pursuing a degree in early childhood education, and professional development opportunities. The Act provides funding for scholarships, teacher support, increased compensation for those pursuing an early childhood education degree, and professional development opportunities for preschool teachers and assistants. This includes training in child development, teacher-child interaction, family engagement, and cultural competence. The Act ensures that grant funds supplement existing Federal, State, and local funds for early childhood educator preparation. States receiving funds must maintain or increase their fiscal effort each year. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
